guild.description:
"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. For God did not send the Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world might be saved through Him. He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God. 

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.

meta_description: The church is getting a lot of criticism lately. Sometimes it's underserved. Sometimes it's not. Here are 5 stupid things the church needs to stop doing.
meta_title: 5 Stupid Things The Church Needs to Stop Doing to Make Progress - CareyNieuwhof.com
title: 5 Stupid Things The Church Needs to Stop Doing

author.bio: Just a guy on the internet who's avatar is a giant mutant crocodile. In my spare time I make wooden things, 3D artwork and work on my tabletop RPG, Destructive Tendencies.
author.bio_html: Just a guy on the internet who's avatar is a giant mutant crocodile. In my spare time I make wooden things, 3D artwork and work on my tabletop RPG, Destructive Tendencies.

body:
TLDR and my commentary:

1. Being weird online: Yeah I can get behind this. I think a lot of it stems from the fact that people read comments in their heads with added intent that just cannot be gleaned from most text posts. If there is any hint of someone else being irate or snarky in their text we hear that in our heads, whether that was their intent or not. I try not to be so reactionary to text posts, but even I fail most of the time. The solution may be to read a comment a few times and try to have a better understanding, or just to try and hear it in our heads as not being combatitive.

2. Commenting on politics: This is malarkey. Yeah Jesus and Paul didn't speak much about politics because their cause was not political but spiritual. That doesn't mean that we as christians shouldn't speak against a political party that is doing evil and speak up for one that is doing good. I've long held that lack of political involvement has lead us to where we are now in America, in a position where the godless run academia, big tech, the media and the government. Stop backing down from politics, but learn to control being hot-headed about it, which can lead to going off the rails and give christians a bad name.

3. Handling conflict poorly: I would venture to say that many christians have no idea how to handle conflict in a productive manner. We either avoid it altogether or try to run someone over because we can't figure out any other argument except, "The bible is right" and "Jesus is lord". Though these are truthful the unsaved have no concept of why they should ascribe to these same things.

4. Ranking sin selectively: Yes the church needs to get this under control, but the modern church also needs a refresher on what actual sin is, since many have no idea. Divorce is rampant and widely accepted in the Western church while even looking at a woman and thinking she looks nice is considered sin. Likely this will never be adjusted on a wide scale.

5. Judging outsiders: We are not called to judge the unsaved but to wisely cast judgement on those who call themselves part of the body. However this doesn't mean that we cannot make judgements on the behavior of "outsiders" and determine that they are doing good or ill and then make judgements based on that. Do you want to associate with that person? Do you trust that person? You cannot judge the status of their salvation but you most certainly can, and should, judge the content of their character.

Overall an interesting read, but it seems a little whiney to me.

Remember: History repeats, and the unaware are doomed to repeat it.

body:
1. Yeah I do that too. Even talking about it now could be considered combative. It's such a primal instinct that it's difficult to even realize when you're doing it. I think the only solution is to always take a few steps back and try to consider where the other person is coming from rather than rushing to shove ourselves in their face.

2. I'm not aware of any political parties doing good. I don't even think that's *possible*. This world is run by satan and the ones who want to control people (which is what politics is really) will of course always be the ones running politics. There's nothing wrong with criticizing a political movement but you should never align and submit to a particular platform. What we're seeing right now is a faction of the republican party pretty much running the churches (democrats sometimes too but that's nowhere near as common as they openly hate Christians). I've noticed that whenever the conservative belief contradicts Christianity they will nearly always opt for the former, which is a red flag that they may not actually be true believers and merely use "God" as a political tool. This is REALLY bad. "You shall not bear the name of 𐤉𐤄𐤅𐤄 your god for falsehood" (Exodus 20:7). (I am not accusing anyone of this, it is merely a suspicion of mine that this is a growing problem). In some ways they have strayed very far from the faith. We were never commanded to support any political party, and in aligning with worldly movements we are effectively making ourselves friends of the world, which makes enmity with God.

3. Mostly because they're taught that they're just always right all their lives and never really stop to think about it or ponder it. Infants in Christ.

4. Even more rampant than divorce is pride. Self-righteous behavior, virtue signaling, bragging about good works, etc. it's all "we're better than you unbelievers" like the freemasons do with their "making good men better" clubs. Definitely not what we're supposed to be doing, and that's all half the churches are nowadays. A close second is wrath and unwillingness to forgive. Well, at least for *certain* things, some of which are completely made up. No one bats an eye at other serious things like lying, gossiping, divorce, pride, hate, revenge, etc. and even encourages them. Unless they're the victims of it, of course, *then* it's a problem.

5. This is true but lately a lot of churches have become almost all about that. A lot of church services now are nothing but "this is the outsiders and we don't do all the stuff they're doing because we're better than them". They do it to elevate themselves, and not for the purpose of warnning people about those who are untrustworthy.

parent.body:
TLDR and my commentary:

1. Being weird online: Yeah I can get behind this. I think a lot of it stems from the fact that people read comments in their heads with added intent that just cannot be gleaned from most text posts. If there is any hint of someone else being irate or snarky in their text we hear that in our heads, whether that was their intent or not. I try not to be so reactionary to text posts, but even I fail most of the time. The solution may be to read a comment a few times and try to have a better understanding, or just to try and hear it in our heads as not being combatitive.

2. Commenting on politics: This is malarkey. Yeah Jesus and Paul didn't speak much about politics because their cause was not political but spiritual. That doesn't mean that we as christians shouldn't speak against a political party that is doing evil and speak up for one that is doing good. I've long held that lack of political involvement has lead us to where we are now in America, in a position where the godless run academia, big tech, the media and the government. Stop backing down from politics, but learn to control being hot-headed about it, which can lead to going off the rails and give christians a bad name.

3. Handling conflict poorly: I would venture to say that many christians have no idea how to handle conflict in a productive manner. We either avoid it altogether or try to run someone over because we can't figure out any other argument except, "The bible is right" and "Jesus is lord". Though these are truthful the unsaved have no concept of why they should ascribe to these same things.

4. Ranking sin selectively: Yes the church needs to get this under control, but the modern church also needs a refresher on what actual sin is, since many have no idea. Divorce is rampant and widely accepted in the Western church while even looking at a woman and thinking she looks nice is considered sin. Likely this will never be adjusted on a wide scale.

5. Judging outsiders: We are not called to judge the unsaved but to wisely cast judgement on those who call themselves part of the body. However this doesn't mean that we cannot make judgements on the behavior of "outsiders" and determine that they are doing good or ill and then make judgements based on that. Do you want to associate with that person? Do you trust that person? You cannot judge the status of their salvation but you most certainly can, and should, judge the content of their character.

Overall an interesting read, but it seems a little whiney to me.
